Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Thalamocortical Interactions: Thalamic Circuits for Perception, Cognition and Action, Ventura, California, February 16-21,2020
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide support to US-based students and post-doctoral fellows and junior scientists to attend the 2020 Gordon Research Conference and Research seminare on Thalamocortical Interactions. This five-day meeting is the premier meeting that brings together researchers to present results and enagage in discussions on the cell and circuit properties of thalamocortical interactions, and build on these to explore their roles in cognition and behavior. This conference represents a rare opportunity for neuroscientists interested in thalamocortical interactions to exchange new results, hypotheses, and ideas at many levels, from cellular through systems to cognitive and clinical. This is especially timely because this field has been expanding significantly with the recent appreciation that the thalamus plays an ongoing and critical role in cortical functioning.

The intellectual merit of this meeting derives from its small size, which promotes interactions between participants, and the assembly of many top scientists whose research spans thalamocortical interactions across multiple sensory modalities, emphasizing the commonalities. This combination leads to fruitful comparative analyses, raises new questions about underlying mechanisms and often leads to new collaborations. By maximizing both formal discussion and informal interactions, the Gordon Conference will highlight exciting new developments that have implications both for a basic understanding of the emergent properties of neural circuits as well as pathologies that involve thalamocortical disruptions. With respect to broader impacts, this meeting will benefit the larger community in multiple ways. First, it will help train and inspire the next generation of scientists by exposing students and postdoctoral fellows to exciting science and scientists. Second, special emphasis will be given to junior faculty. Finally, a concerted effort will be made to recruit scientists from under-represented groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The thalamus is intimately interconnected with the cerebral cortex, and thalamocortical connections are a ubiquitous feature of brain organization. With recent technical advances, our views of thalamocortical interactions and their contribution to brain function and dysfunction are rapidly evolving. It is becoming increasingly clear that the thalamus and cortex are dynamic partners in the processing of signals essential for sensory perception, the initiation of complex actions, as well as higher-order cognitive functions. Thalamocortical networks are also sensitive to disease states that can have devastating consequences for individuals and society.

 

The 2020 Thalamocortical Gordon Research Conference (GRC) served as an important venue to nurture and draw attention to the role of the thalamus in cognitive realms, and help to disseminate novel ideas of thalamic function. This conference brought together scientists with diverse perspectives and technical expertise from across the world to share and discuss the latest basic and translational research discoveries, and to promote community interaction and collaboration. It was the hope of the organizers that meeting participants formed a critical mass to shape thalamic research in the next decade. To cultivate the integration and professional advancement of junior investigators, each morning session included a series of 2-minute/1-slide oral "Poster Preview" presentations (chosen from submitted abstracts), and each evening session included a 10-minute "Short Talk" (chosen from submitted abstracts).

 

The focus of the 2020 the Thalamocortical Interactions Gordon Research Seminar was on thalamocortical interactions and their role in brain function, dysfunction, and their promise as a target for neurological disorders. The seminar featured 3 scientific oral presentation sessions, 2 poster sessions, and 1 career development session. Two scientific oral presentation sessions were dedicated to the exciting new areas of thalamocortical research including higher order processing and behavioral states (including arousal, attention, and sleep), while the third session focused on translational research.

The seminar hosted a career development session titled "Academia and Beyond", which had a panel of 3-4 mentors from different career stages and tracts - where they provided their experiences and advice on transitioning from graduate students or post docs into the job market. This session focused primarily on career choices and transitions outside of academia. The session consisted of panel and group discussions, allowing young scientists to explore diverse career choices and foster cross discipline communication and research.

With the GRS's small and intimate atmosphere, participants had the opportunity to make personal connections and network with people in their field, share and exchange ideas, find potential collaborators, and learn how to be successful scientists.
